awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: The Social Functions of Monumentality
awd_abstract_narration:
Monuments have played an important role in human societies for at least the last ten millennia by structuring relationships between people, histories, and landscapes. Archaeologists explore these relationships through the framework of "monumentality." Historically, monuments were associated a priori with complex societies following a notion that the necessary labor for their construction must inherently be organized by hierarchically-empowered leaders and supported by agricultural surplus. This project adds to an emerging global record of contrary examples by exploring the role of monuments in small-scale societies. The near absence of ethnographic or ethnohistoric records of monument construction among small-scale societies leaves archaeology as the sole domain for inquiry. The Eastern Woodlands of North America have recently assumed a prominent place in this discussion, but the region's most enigmatic monuments "the large geometric earthworks of the Scioto Hopewell" have yet to enter this consideration in a meaningful way. This research centers Scioto Hopewell monumentality and provides a comparative framework through which to understand monumentality in other small-scale societies. That monuments still play a large and active role in society has been made apparent as Civil War monuments have dominated recent headlines. This project will bring attention to Native American monuments, which have been destroyed at an alarming rate over the last two centuries, in an effort to facilitate appreciation, knowledge, and conservation of these places. 

University of Michigan doctoral candidate Timothy Everhart will investigate Middle Woodland (AD 1-400) monumentality in the Central Scioto River Valley. Scioto Hopewell societies of this period constructed monuments of a greater density and of a greater diversity than any other known monuments of small-scale societies. By conducting new excavations at the Steel Group site (33Ro62)  - a site with at least 13 earthen monuments of many designs - in Ross County, Ohio, and subjecting recovered materials to a host of laboratory-based analyses, this research will investigate the unique processes and practices of monumentality that led to the construction of different monument forms at the same location. Specifically, it will document the historical trajectory of monument construction, the use of monuments, and the composition of laboring parties at this site. This project will seek to address the range of variation among Hopewell earthworks in the Central Scioto River Valley of southern Ohio, and thus to offer insight into the various roles monuments played in small-scale societies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For at least the last 10 millennia, monuments have played an important role in human societies by structuring relationships between landscapes, people, and histories. Archaeologists explore these relationships through the framework of 'monumentality'. Historically, monuments were associated a priori with complex societies following a notion that the necessary labor for their construction must inherently be organized by hierarchically-empowered leaders and supported by agricultural surplus. This project added important new data to the emerging global record of contrary examples in small-scale societies. Limited ethnographic and ethnohistoric records of monument construction among small-scale societies leaves archaeology as the primary domain for inquiry. The Eastern Woodlands of North America have recently assumed a prominent place in this discussion, but the region's most enigmatic monuments--the large geometric earthworks of the Scioto Hopewell--have played an undersized role in these discussions. This research sought and contributed seminal data pertaining to Scioto Hopewell monumentality, such that these societies and their monuments can better contribute to our understanding of monuments in small-scale societies. It also provided a comparative framework through which to understand monumentality in other small-scale societies and, through this comparative research, provides critical updates to our understanding of monuments derived from Native monuments across North America.

University of Michigan doctoral candidate Timothy Everhart investigated Scioto Hopewell monumentality ca. 1-400 CE in the central Scioto River valley. Scioto Hopewell societies constructed monuments of a greater density and of a greater diversity than any other known small-scale societies. By conducting new excavations at the Steel Group (33Ro62) and Junction Group (33Ro28) sites-- having thirteen and nine earthen monuments respectively--in Ross County, Ohio, data was collected that critically expanded that from which to draw inferences as to the roles and meanings of the monuments across time. Excavations and the preliminary analysis of lithics (debitage), ceramics (stylistic and chemical composition), faunal, and macrobotanical remains suggest the tested earthworks were used in manners that required limited architectural components other than the earthworks themselves (e.g., earthovens, storage pits, buildings). Similarly, additional evidence was collected that suggests their interior spaces may have been cleaned, as sealed contexts within earthworks contained evidence of debris-generating activities (e.g., tool resharpening and feasting). Excavations also revealed that smaller earthworks are architectural complex, involving significant landscape modification beyond those initially apparent. Ongoing Bayesian modeling of AMS radiocarbon dates are revealing the construction tempo and the relative timing of construction and use throughout the region. Similarly, evidence emerged for a unique reuse of some earthworks centuries later. This adds to growing evidence for the varied manners in which these monuments facilitated social memory across history, including in precontact societies.

Though these results are initial, they make clear that earthworks played varied and important roles Scioto Hopewell society. When excavations undertaken for this research are compared to known data from the region, the complexity of design and execution of these monuments comes into sharper relief. The variability in designs is suggestive of decentralized planning for earthwork construction wherein material meaning may have been standardized but builders chose deliberate material juxtapositions and combinations at each earthwork to evoke specific ideas. Although this is inline with evidence from craft production and other ceremonial architecture within Scioto Hopewell society, the implications from large-scale labor projects provides new insight into the Scioto Hopewell writ large.

This project, funded in part by NSF DDRI: 1946936 aimed to bring more awareness and understanding to Scioto Hopewell societies, a people whose unique propensity for monumentalizing their environment bears many lessons pertinent to today. It provided field training to a diverse cohort of nearly 20 students and local volunteers and opportunities for laboratory research for 3 students additional students. It also provided a forum to engage the local community, through open houses and site tours at the excavations, and through public presentations. These and broader public initiatives still ongoing seek to bring attention to Native American monuments more broadly, which have been destroyed at an alarming rate over the last two centuries, in an effort to facilitate appreciation, knowledge, and conservation of these places.
